qas.question: What has a strong influence over all aspect of Tibetans lives?
What is the ancient religion of Tibet?
When were nearly all of Tibet's monasteries destroyed by the Red Guard?
When were 10 to 20% of Tibets males monks?
What has Tibetan Buddhism been almost eclipsed by?
What country introduced Bon into Tibet?

plausible_answers.text: parts of northern India, the Buryat Republic, the Tuva Republic, and in the Republic of Kalmykia and some other parts of China

qas.question: Where is Mongolian Buddhism practiced besides Tibet?
How many males in Tibet were monks in 1950?

context: <a0_0>Religion<a0_0/> is extremely important to the Tibetans and has a strong influence over all aspects of their lives. <a1_0><b4_0>Bön<b4_0/><a1_0/> is the ancient religion of Tibet, but has been almost eclipsed by Tibetan Buddhism, a distinctive form of Mahayana and Vajrayana, which was introduced into Tibet from the Sanskrit Buddhist tradition of northern <b5_0>India<b5_0/>. Tibetan Buddhism is practiced not only in Tibet but also in Mongolia, <b6_0>parts of northern India, the Buryat Republic, the Tuva Republic, and in the Republic of Kalmykia and some other parts of China<b6_0/>. <a2_0>During China's Cultural Revolution<a2_0/>, nearly all Tibet's monasteries were ransacked and destroyed by the Red Guards. A few monasteries have begun to rebuild since the 1980s (with limited support from the Chinese government) and greater religious freedom has been granted – although it is still limited. Monks returned to monasteries across Tibet and monastic education resumed even though the number of monks imposed is strictly limited. <a3_0>Before the 1950s<a3_0/>, <b7_0>between 10 and 20%<b7_0/> of males in Tibet were monks.
